ap-2-1-3.name: Bird Food
ap-2-1-3.notes: Seed-based, lower footprint than meat-based pet food

ap-2-17.name: Pet Collars & Harnesses
ap-2-17.notes: Leather collars have different footprint profile

ap-2-2-1.name: Cat Food
ap-2-2-1.notes: Higher protein content than dog food

ap-2-25.name: Pet Food Scoops
ap-2-25.notes: Stainless steel vs ceramic vs plastic varies

ap-2-3-3.name: Dog Food
sources: Okin (2017) Environmental impacts of food consumption by dogs and cats

ap-2-4-7.name: Aquarium Gravel & Substrates
ap-2-4-7.notes: Low processing, mainly extraction and transport

ap-2-47-2.name: Small Animal Food
ap-2-47-2.notes: Rabbits, guinea pigs, hamsters - mostly hay/grain based

aa-1.name: Clothing
aa-1.notes: Parent category - use subcategories for more accurate estimates

weight.methodology: Broad average across all clothing types

aa-1-1-8-2.name: Jackets
aa-1-1-8-2.notes: Leather has high footprint; faux leather ~60% lower

aa-1-10.name: Outerwear
aa-1-10.notes: High variance - down jackets lighter, winter coats heavier

weight.methodology: Based on standard adult cotton t-shirts

aa-2-6.name: Belts
aa-2-6.notes: Leather belts - synthetic alternatives have ~40% lower footprint

aa-4.name: Handbag & Wallet Accessories
aa-4.notes: Much lower footprint than precious metals

aa-6.name: Jewelry
aa-6.notes: Very small weights but high value and footprint per gram

aa-6-11.name: Watches
aa-6-11.notes: Varies greatly by type - digital vs mechanical

aa-6-3.name: Bracelets
aa-6-3.notes: Precious metals have very high per-kg footprint

aa-6-9.name: Rings
aa-6-9.notes: Gold rings - silver and costume jewelry much lower

aa-8.name: Shoes
aa-8.notes: Wide variance between sandals and boots

aa-8-3.name: Boots
aa-8-3.notes: Leather boots have higher footprint than synthetic

ae-2-1.name: Arts & Crafts
ae-2-1.notes: Highly variable category - weights depend on medium and quantity

ae-2-1-1.name: Art & Craft Kits
sources: European Oleochemicals & Allied Products Group LCA data

ae-2-1-2-12-1-1.name: Clay
ae-2-1-2-12-1-1.notes: Low embodied carbon but firing adds significant energy use

ae-2-1-2-14-2.name: Fabric
ae-2-1-2-14-2.notes: Varies significantly by fabric type and weight

ae-2-1-2-17-1-1.name: Raw Candle Wax
ae-2-1-2-17-1-1.notes: Soy wax ~2.0 kg CO2e/kg, paraffin ~3.5 kg CO2e/kg

ae-2-8.name: Musical Instruments
ae-2-8.notes: Extremely variable - from harmonicas to pianos

bt-10-16-6.name: Baby Bottles
bt-10-16-6.notes: Glass bottles heavier but lower footprint per use

bt-4-3.name: Baby Monitors
bt-4-3.notes: Video monitors have higher footprint than audio-only

bt-9.name: Diapering
bt-9.notes: Per diaper vs per pack varies greatly

bt-9-12-1.name: Cloth Diapers
bt-9-12-1.notes: Higher upfront footprint but reusable; washing impacts vary

bt-9-12-2.name: Disposable Diapers
bt-9-12-2.notes: Per-use footprint; cloth diapers have different profile

fr-1.name: Baby & Toddler Furniture
fr-1.notes: Scaled down versions - lighter than adult furniture

el-17-1.name: Computer Monitors
el-17-1.notes: Weight and impact scales significantly with screen size

el-2.name: Audio
el-2.notes: Extremely variable - earbuds to home theater systems

el-2-2-10.name: Speakers
el-2-2-10.notes: Portable bluetooth speakers ~300g, home speakers much heavier

lca.methodology: Smartphone average based on manufacturer reports
Based on Dell and HP sustainability reports

fr-15.name: Outdoor Furniture
fr-15.notes: See Furniture vertical for more detail

hb-3-10-10.name: Hair Styling Products
hb-3-10-10.notes: Aerosols have higher footprint than gels/creams

hb-3-2-1-1.name: Bar Soap
hb-3-2-1-1.notes: Lower packaging footprint than liquid soap

hb-3-2-6.name: Makeup
hb-3-2-6.notes: Very small products with significant packaging

hb-3-2-9.name: Skin Care
hb-3-2-9.notes: Product weight varies; packaging adds significantly

hb-3-2-9-13.name: Skin Care Masks & Peels
hb-3-2-9-13.notes: Sheet masks have high packaging-to-product ratio

hb-3-2-9-19.name: Eye Creams
hb-3-2-9-19.notes: Small size means high packaging ratio

hb-3-2-9-20.name: Face Moisturizers
hb-3-2-9-20.notes: Glass jars have higher packaging footprint than tubes

ha-8-3-3.name: Thermostats
ha-8-3-3.notes: Smart thermostats save significant energy use

hg-11.name: Kitchen & Dining
hg-11.notes: Highly variable - from utensils to appliances

hg-11-10-5.name: Drinkware
hg-11-10-5.notes: Glass and ceramic have different footprints

hg-11-7.name: Kitchen Appliances
hg-11-7.notes: Very high variance - toasters to refrigerators

hg-12.name: Lawn & Garden
hg-12.notes: Extremely variable - seeds to lawn mowers

hg-13-7.name: Light Bulbs
hg-13-7.notes: LED bulbs - incandescent have much higher use-phase impact

hg-15-1-5.name: Duvet Covers
hg-15-1-5.notes: Down-filled have higher footprint than synthetic

hg-3-57.name: Rugs
hg-3-57.notes: Weight varies significantly with size and material

hg-3-6.name: Baskets
hg-3-6.notes: Natural materials vs plastic varies significantly

lb-12.name: Suitcases
lb-12.notes: LCA data needed - varies significantly by material

sg-1-2-10.name: Baseball Bats
sg-1-2-10.notes: Aluminum bats heavier (~850g) with higher footprint

sg-2.notes: Ranges from resistance bands to treadmills

weight.methodology: Per single dumbbell - varies by weight class

sg-2-26.name: Yoga & Pilates
sg-2-26.notes: TPE/natural rubber mats have lower footprint

sg-4-2-14.name: Sleeping Bags
sg-4-2-14.notes: Down-filled bags have different footprint profile

sg-4-4-3-11.notes: Carbon frames have higher embodied carbon but lower weight

sg-4-4-3-5.name: Electric Bikes
sg-4-4-3-5.notes: Battery production is significant portion of footprint

el-18.name: Video Game Console Accessories
el-18.notes: Physical media vs consoles have huge weight difference

tg-2-9.notes: Weight varies by material - wood vs plastic vs stone

tg-5-20-1.notes: Battery adds significant weight and footprint

weight.methodology: Varies by set size - average medium set

tg-5-7-14.name: Wooden Blocks
tg-5-7-14.notes: Lower footprint than plastic, potential carbon storage
